definitions.definition: A tiny woodland arachnid of the suborder Ixodida.
A relatively quiet but sharp sound generally made repeatedly by moving machinery.
definitions.example: The steady tick of the clock provided a comforting background for the conversation.

definitions.definition: A mark on any scale of measurement; a unit of measurement.
definitions.example: At midday, the long bond is up a tick.

definitions.definition: A jiffy (unit of time defined by basic timer frequency).
A short period of time, particularly a second.
definitions.example: I'll be back in a tick.

definitions.definition: A periodic increment of damage or healing caused by an ongoing status effect.
A mark (✓) made to indicate agreement, correctness or acknowledgement.
definitions.example: Indicate that you are willing to receive marketing material by putting a tick in the box

definitions.definition: A bird seen (or heard) by a birdwatcher, for the first time that day, year, trip, etc., and thus added to a list of observed birds.
The whinchat.
To make a clicking noise similar to the movement of the hands in an analog clock.
To make a tick or checkmark.
To work or operate, especially mechanically.
definitions.example: He took the computer apart to see how it ticked.

definitions.definition: To strike gently; to pat.
To add a bird to a list of birds that have been seen (or heard).
Ticking.
A sheet that wraps around a mattress; the cover of a mattress, containing the filling.
Credit, trust.
To go on trust, or credit.
To give tick; to trust.
(place names) A goat.
